<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 120, 645, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 195, 280, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 171, 905, 230]]<|/det|>
9702/11 May/June 2025 1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 250, 506, 264]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 280, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 339, 227, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 355, 905, 504]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 533, 219, 546]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 570, 596]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 702, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 460, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
The distance from X to Y is 3.0 m . The work done against the frictional force in moving the box from X to Y is 150 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 777, 522]]<|/det|>
The work done against the frictional force in moving the box from Y to Z is 200 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 535, 591, 552]]<|/det|>
An identical box Q is pushed in a straight line from X to Z .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 565, 808, 582]]<|/det|>
The magnitude of the frictional force between the boxes and the surface is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 595, 752, 612]]<|/det|>
How much extra work is done against the frictional force in moving P than Q?

<label>A</label>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 623, 700, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>600 J</label>

<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 669, 604, 686]]<|/det|>
19 The momentum of a car of mass \(m\) increases from \(p_{1}\) to \(p_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 699, 551, 715]]<|/det|>
What is the increase in the kinetic energy of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 725, 144, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 724, 720, 758]]<|/det|>
A \(\frac{(p_{2}{}^{2}-p_{1}{}^{2})}{2m}\) \(\frac{(p_{2}-p_{1})^{2}}{2m}\) \(\frac{p_{2}-p_{1}}{2m}\) \(\frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{2m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 551, 91]]<|/det|>
20 A parachutist is falling at constant (terminal) velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 384, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 131, 144, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 131, 738, 149]]<|/det|>
A Gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 159, 144, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 158, 808, 176]]<|/det|>
B Gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of the parachutist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 185, 144, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 184, 747, 202]]<|/det|>
C Gravitational potential energy is converted into thermal energy of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 211, 144, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 210, 816, 227]]<|/det|>
D Gravitational potential energy is converted into thermal energy of the parachutist.

<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 255, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
21 A student investigates a spring. The variation of the length of the spring with the force applied to the spring is shown.

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 479, 730, 497]]<|/det|>
A \(0.17 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}\) B \(0.25 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}\) C \(4.0 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}\) D \(6.0 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 526, 114, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 526, 670, 543]]<|/det|>
22 The graph shows the variation with force of the extension of a wire.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 554, 735, 710]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 725, 900, 742]]<|/det|>
The force is gradually increased to a maximum at Q and then gradually decreased to zero at R .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 756, 350, 772]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 784, 144, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 783, 541, 801]]<|/det|>
A Along the line PQ, the wire obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 812, 144, 829]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 808, 655, 833]]<|/det|>
B Along the line RP, the spring constant is equal to \(\frac{\text{extension}}{\text{force}}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 841, 144, 857]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 840, 514, 857]]<|/det|>
C The wire has elastic deformation at point Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 868, 144, 885]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 867, 828, 885]]<|/det|>
D The work done in stretching the wire to P is equal to (force \(\times\) extension) at point P .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 73, 114, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 693, 91]]<|/det|> 23 A uniform metal wire of length \(L\) and diameter \(d\) has spring constant \(k\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 460, 120]]<|/det|> What is the Young modulus of the metal? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 128, 144, 154]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 128, 695, 160]]<|/det|> A \(\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4 k L}\) B \(\frac{\pi d^{2}}{k L}\) C \(\frac{k L}{\pi d^{2}}\) D \(\frac{4 k L}{\pi d^{2}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 192, 114, 208]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 192, 571, 208]]<|/det|> 24 An aircraft produces a sound at a frequency of 30.0 Hz . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 222, 433, 238]]<|/det|> The speed of sound in air is \(330 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 253, 920, 284]]<|/det|> The aircraft is directly in front of the stationary observer and travels in a straight line towards or away from the observer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 297, 717, 314]]<|/det|> The observer hears the sound from the aircraft at a frequency of 20.0 Hz . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 328, 504, 344]]<|/det|> What is the speed and direction of the aircraft? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 356, 510, 485]]<|/det|>
speed/m s-1direction
A110away from observer
B110towards observer
C165away from observer
D165towards observer
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 514, 114, 530]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 514, 920, 543]]<|/det|> 25 Which statement about longitudinal and transverse wave motion for a progressive wave is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 556, 144, 572]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 555, 744, 572]]<|/det|> A All transverse and longitudinal waves require a medium for propagation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 583, 144, 599]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 581, 920, 612]]<|/det|> B All transverse waves travel at the same speed, but longitudinal waves can travel at different speeds. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 623, 144, 639]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 622, 920, 653]]<|/det|> C In both transverse waves and longitudinal waves, a particle with zero displacement has a maximum speed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 663, 144, 679]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 662, 920, 693]]<|/det|> D In a longitudinal wave there is a net movement of particles in the direction of travel of the wave, but there is no net movement of particles in a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 723, 114, 739]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 723, 892, 739]]<|/det|> 26 The diagram shows a progressive transverse wave on a stretched string at one instant in time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 753, 418, 770]]<|/det|> One point on the string is labelled X . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 783, 560, 800]]<|/det|> Which point on the string is \(270^{\circ}\) out of phase with X ? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 810, 672, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 562, 222, 578]]<|/det|>
0.050Ω

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 562, 369, 578]]<|/det|>
B 1.6Ω

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 562, 529, 578]]<|/det|>
C 20Ω

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 562, 695, 578]]<|/det|>
D 23Ω

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 607, 114, 623]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 607, 505, 623]]<|/det|>
38 Which list contains only fundamental particles?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 636, 144, 652]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 636, 507, 652]]<|/det|>
A antineutrinos, baryons, neutrons, electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 663, 144, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 663, 467, 679]]<|/det|>
B mesons, electrons, neutrinos, protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 689, 144, 705]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 689, 447, 705]]<|/det|>
C positrons, quarks, hadrons, protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 715, 144, 731]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 715, 454, 731]]<|/det|>
D quarks, positrons, neutrinos, leptons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 116, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
39 Which statement explains why alpha-particles have discrete energies, but beta-particles have a continuous range of energies?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 117, 134, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 117, 918, 148]]<|/det|>
A Beta-particles have a much smaller mass than alpha-particles which means beta-particles can be emitted with a larger range of velocities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 159, 134, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 158, 918, 189]]<|/det|>
B Only alpha-particles experience repulsion from the nucleus which is dependent on the number of protons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 200, 134, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 199, 918, 230]]<|/det|>
C Only beta-particles are emitted with another lepton and some energy is transferred to the other lepton.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 241, 134, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 240, 918, 271]]<|/det|>
D Only the energy of alpha-particles is discrete because the composition of alpha-particles is always the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 300, 116, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 300, 548, 316]]<|/det|>
40 A hadron consists of antiquarks that are all identical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 330, 876, 347]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 358, 134, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 358, 180, 375]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 358, 355, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>B +1e</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 358, 522, 375]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 358, 688, 375]]<|/det|>
